title: How to Make a Parachute With a Plastic Bag and a Straw

steps.headline: Cut a flexible straw into 8 equal parts lengthwise, as shown in the image.
steps.description:
Only cut down to the concertina flex part of the straw and not beyond. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Para2_742.JPG/459px-Para2_742.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Para2_742.JPG/759px-Para2_742.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.9560439560439,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

steps.headline: Fold over the other end of the straw (the uncut portion) slightly and hold in place with pliers.
steps.description:
Seal this end together using a flame: Hold the end in place with the pliers. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/DVC00195_45.JPG/460px-DVC00195_45.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/f9/DVC00195_45.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} With care, use the naked flame to heat seal together. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/DVC00194_713.JPG/460px-DVC00194_713.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3c/DVC00194_713.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: Stick double-sided tape on each of 8 cut ends of the straw.
steps.description:
Bend over the end, with the double-sided tape intact. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Para4_701.JPG/460px-Para4_701.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Para4_701.JPG/760px-Para4_701.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

steps.headline: Find a plastic bag and smooth it out to remove wrinkles.
steps.description:
Cut off the handles and the base, as shown in the image. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/DVC00012_903.JPG/460px-DVC00012_903.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/cc/DVC00012_903.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Cut out a rough square shape as shown in the image. The square should measure about 35 centimeter (13.8 in) x 35 centimeter (13.8 in) / 13.7" x 13.7". {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/DVC00013_88.JPG/460px-DVC00013_88.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/5b/DVC00013_88.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Fold like origami. Fold in half, then a quarter, then an eighth, and then a sixteenth (1/2>1/4>1/8>1/16). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/DVC00014_87.JPG/460px-DVC00014_87.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/ec/DVC00014_87.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Once folded, cut the folded piece a length of 15 centimeter (5.9 in) / 5.9" radius. Cut off this excess, so it'll form an isosceles triangle. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/DVC00015_438.JPG/460px-DVC00015_438.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/02/DVC00015_438.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Unfold the circle. You'll see that the fold lines remain clearly, indicating suitable positioning of the parachute strings to ensure even balance. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/DVC00016_953.JPG/460px-DVC00016_953.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/00/DVC00016_953.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: Attach each of the eight cut straw pieces with double-sided tape.
steps.description:
Stick the sticky side alongside one fold line. Continue working your way around the entire parachute using even positioning, as shown in the image. It's helpful to click and enlarge this image to follow it more easily. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Para6a_30.JPG/460px-Para6a_30.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Para6a_30.JPG/760px-Para6a_30.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} The appearance at this stage. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Para6b_911.JPG/460px-Para6b_911.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Para6b_911.JPG/760px-Para6b_911.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":461,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":761.3595706618962,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Para7_532.JPG/460px-Para7_532.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Para7_532.JPG/760px-Para7_532.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

steps.headline: Weight and stopper the open portion of the straw.
steps.description:
Where the cut lengths of the parachute meet the concertina flex of the straw, there remains an open hole. In order to weight the parachute for smooth floating, you'll need to fill this with some small beads. Carefully funnel the small beads into the hole. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Para9_833.JPG/460px-Para9_833.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Para9_833.JPG/759px-Para9_833.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":567.9120879120879,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} Seal the beads in by corking it with tissue pieces. Make sure it is firm so that the beads don't come tumbling out. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Para10_705.JPG/460px-Para10_705.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Para10_705.JPG/760px-Para10_705.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

steps.headline: Decorate the parachute if wished.
steps.description: While this step isn't necessary, it's also fun and it personalizes the parachute. A great activity for kids during the holidays or on rainy weekends!

steps.headline: Play with your newly made parachute.
steps.description: Throw it into the air on an angle. It should go up like an umbrella. Release and watch it drop.

tyn: Plastic bag (loose and flexible / 35cm x 35cm / 13.7" x 13.7" per square); be careful if using a biodegradable plastic bag as it won't last long and will disintegrate in the sunlight - it will only be a temporary toy or decoration

Only cut down to the concertina flex part of the straw and not beyond.

In order to weight the parachute for smooth floating, you'll need to fill this with some small beads.

It should go up like an umbrella.
Release and watch it drop.
